Class FSMBuilder

This is your primary tool for creating and setting up new FSMs (Finite State Machines). üõ†Ô∏è Think of it as a special "construction kit" that lets you easily build complex FSM blueprints step-by-step.

graph TD A(Create.CreateFiniteStateMachine) --> B(State); B --> B; B --> C(WithInitialState); C --> D(Transition); D --> D; D --> E(AnyTransition); E --> E; E --> F(BuildDefinition);

Namespace: TheSingularityWorkshop.FSM_API
Assembly: FSM_API.dll
Syntax
public class FSMBuilder
Remarks

The FSMBuilder is designed to be very user-friendly, allowing you to define how your FSM works in a clear, flowing way (this is called a "fluent API"). Even if you're not a seasoned coder, you can use this builder to:

  • Define each **state** the FSM can be in (like "Idle" or "Running").
  • Set up the **rules (transitions)** for moving between these states.
  • Choose the FSM's **starting state**.
  • And decide **how often** the FSM should check its rules.

You typically use this builder once during your application's setup to create the FSM's blueprint. After the blueprint is built, you then create **instances** of that FSM using an FSMHandle to actually make things happen in your game or application.

The methods in this builder are designed to be "chained" together, making your FSM definitions very readable, almost like telling a story of how your FSM behaves. Once you're done setting everything up, you call BuildDefinition() to save your FSM blueprint and make it available for use.

Here's a simple example of building an FSM for a player character, showing how readable it can be: 
// First, define a "context" (a data bag) for your player FSM.
// This is where you'll store specific player information like if they are moving or jumping.
public class PlayerContext : IStateContext
{
    public string PlayerName { get; set; } = "Hero";
    public bool IsMoving { get; set; } = false;
    public bool HasJumped { get; set; } = false;
}

// Now, use the FSMBuilder to create your "PlayerFSM" blueprint.
// We want it to update 60 times per second and be part of the "GameLoop" group.
FSM_API.Create.CreateFiniteStateMachine("PlayerFSM", 60, "GameLoop")
// Define the "Idle" state: what happens when entering, during updates, and when exiting.
.State("Idle",
onEnter: (ctx) => Console.WriteLine($"{((PlayerContext)ctx).PlayerName} is now Idle."),
onUpdate: (ctx) => { /* Check for player input to move or jump / },
onExit: (ctx) => Console.WriteLine($"{((PlayerContext)ctx).PlayerName} stopped being Idle."))
// Define the "Moving" state.
.State("Moving",
onEnter: (ctx) => Console.WriteLine($"{((PlayerContext)ctx).PlayerName} started Moving."),
onUpdate: (ctx) => { / Handle continuous movement, check if player stops or jumps / },
onExit: (ctx) => Console.WriteLine($"{((PlayerContext)ctx).PlayerName} stopped Moving."))
// Define the "Jumping" state.
.State("Jumping",
onEnter: (ctx) => Console.WriteLine($"{((PlayerContext)ctx).PlayerName} is Jumping!"),
onUpdate: (ctx) => { / Apply jump physics, check for landing */ },
onExit: (ctx) => Console.WriteLine($"{((PlayerContext)ctx).PlayerName} landed."))
// Tell the FSM that "Idle" is the very first state a new instance will start in.
.WithInitialState("Idle")
// Set up the rules (transitions) for how the FSM moves between states.
// These conditions check the player's data in the PlayerContext.
.Transition("Idle", "Moving", (ctx) => ((PlayerContext)ctx).IsMoving)
.Transition("Moving", "Idle", (ctx) => !((PlayerContext)ctx).IsMoving)
.Transition("Moving", "Jumping", (ctx) => ((PlayerContext)ctx).HasJumped)
.Transition("Idle", "Jumping", (ctx) => ((PlayerContext)ctx).HasJumped)
// This is an "Any-State" transition: from any current state, if the player
// has jumped AND is no longer moving, transition back to "Idle" (e.g., they landed).
.Transition(FSM.AnyStateIdentifier, "Idle", (ctx) => ((PlayerContext)ctx).HasJumped && !((PlayerContext)ctx).IsMoving)
// Finish building and save this FSM blueprint so you can create live instances from it.
.BuildDefinition();

Constructors

FSMBuilder(string, int, string)

Starts a new FSMBuilder to help you create a brand-new FSM blueprint.

Declaration
public FSMBuilder(string fsmName, int processRate = 0, string processingGroup = "Update")
Parameters
Type Name Description
string fsmName

The unique name for your new FSM blueprint (e.g., "PlayerMovementFSM").
int processRate

How often instances of this FSM should automatically update. See ProcessRate for details.
string processingGroup

A name for a group this FSM belongs to, which helps organize updates. See ProcessingGroup for details.
Remarks

You usually won't call this directly. Instead, you'll use a helper method like CreateFiniteStateMachine(string, int, string), which then uses this behind the scenes.

Methods

| Edit this page View Source

AnyTransition(string, Func<IStateContext, bool>)

Adds a global "Any State" transition to your FSM blueprint. üåç

Declaration
public FSMBuilder AnyTransition(string to, Func<IStateContext, bool> condition)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string to

The name of the state the FSM will move to if this "Any State" transition's condition is met.
Func<IStateContext, bool> condition

A function (rule) that must return true for this global transition to occur. This function receives the IStateContext (your FSM's data bag) to evaluate the condition.
Returns
Type Description
FSMBuilder

The builder itself, for chaining more commands.
Remarks

An "Any State" transition is unique because its condition is checked regardless of which state the FSM is currently in. If the condition returns true, the FSM will immediately transition to the specified to state. These transitions are typically evaluated before regular, state-specific transitions. If you add multiple "Any State" transitions that lead to the same to state, the last one added will replace any previous ones leading to that same target.

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentException

Thrown if the to state name is empty.
ArgumentNullException

Thrown if the condition function is null.
| Edit this page View Source

BuildDefinition()

Finalizes your FSM blueprint and registers it with the FSM system. ‚úÖ

Declaration
public void BuildDefinition()
Remarks

After calling this, your FSM blueprint is complete and saved. You can then start creating live instances of it using CreateInstance(string, IStateContext, string).

This method checks for common mistakes like:

  • If the FSM `Name` is empty.
  • If no states have been added.
  • If the `InitialState` you set actually exists.
If an FSM blueprint with the same name already exists in the system when `BuildDefinition` is called, it will be **overwritten** with this new definition.
Exceptions
Type Condition
InvalidOperationException

Thrown if the FSM has no name, no states, or the initial state doesn't exist.
| Edit this page View Source

State(string, Action<IStateContext>, Action<IStateContext>, Action<IStateContext>)

Adds or updates a "state" for your FSM blueprint. This is where you define what happens when your FSM is in a particular condition or mode.

Declaration
public FSMBuilder State(string name, Action<IStateContext> onEnter, Action<IStateContext> onUpdate, Action<IStateContext> onExit)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string name

The unique name for this state (e.g., "Idle", "Attacking").
Action<IStateContext> onEnter

An optional action to run when entering this state.
Action<IStateContext> onUpdate

An optional action to run repeatedly while in this state.
Action<IStateContext> onExit

An optional action to run when exiting this state.
Returns
Type Description
FSMBuilder

The builder itself, so you can chain more commands.
Remarks

Each state needs a unique name. If you try to add a state with the same name twice, you'll get an error.

You also define three key actions for each state:

  • onEnter:What happens **when the FSM first enters** this state.
  • onUpdate:What happens **repeatedly while the FSM is in** this state.
  • onExit:What happens **just before the FSM leaves** this state.
These actions receive a `context` (your IStateContext data bag) which lets them interact with the specific object or system that this FSM instance belongs to. You can provide `null` for any action if nothing specific needs to happen at that point.
Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentException

Happens if the state name is empty or a state with that name already exists.
| Edit this page View Source

Transition(string, string, Func<IStateContext, bool>)

Defines a rule (transition) for your FSM to move from one specific state to another.

Declaration
public FSMBuilder Transition(string from, string to, Func<IStateContext, bool> condition)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string from

The name of the state where this transition starts.
string to

The name of the state where this transition leads to.
Func<IStateContext, bool> condition

A function (rule) that must return true for this transition to happen. This function receives the IStateContext (your FSM's data bag).
Returns
Type Description
FSMBuilder

The builder itself, for chaining.
Remarks

This transition rule will only be considered when the FSM is currently in the from state. If you define multiple transitions between the exact same from and to states, the last one you define will replace any earlier ones.

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentException

Happens if from or to state names are empty, or if the condition is null.
| Edit this page View Source

WithInitialState(string)

Sets the starting state for any new FSM instance created from this blueprint.

Declaration
public FSMBuilder WithInitialState(string stateName)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string stateName

The name of the state that new FSM instances should start in.
Returns
Type Description
FSMBuilder

The builder itself, for chaining.
Remarks

When an FSM instance is first created, it will immediately enter this state. Make sure you've already defined this state using the State(string, Action<IStateContext>, Action<IStateContext>, Action<IStateContext>) method.

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentException

Happens if the stateName is empty.
| Edit this page View Source

WithProcessRate(int)

Sets how often instances of this FSM blueprint should automatically check and update themselves.

Declaration
public FSMBuilder WithProcessRate(int rate)
Parameters
Type Name Description
int rate

The desired update rate.
Returns
Type Description
FSMBuilder

The builder itself, for chaining.
Remarks

This controls the "Process Rate". See ProcessRate for a detailed explanation:

  • -1Update **every single time** the FSM's group is processed.
  • 0Update **only when you manually tell it to** (no automatic updates).
  • >0Update **every Nth time** the FSM's group is processed (e.g., 5 means every 5th update).
| Edit this page View Source

WithProcessingGroup(string)

Sets the "processing group" name for this FSM blueprint.

Declaration
public FSMBuilder WithProcessingGroup(string groupName)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string groupName

The name of the processing group (e.g., "GameLoop", "UIA", "PhysicsUpdate").
Returns
Type Description
FSMBuilder

The builder itself, for chaining.
Remarks

This helps organize your FSMs into categories. You can then tell the FSM system to update all FSMs in a specific group at once. See ProcessingGroup for more context.

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentException

Happens if the groupName is empty.
